mods.abstract: ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS REWARD will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of the slave JOE, if taken out of the State, and Fifty Dollars if found in the city alive. He was seen at his quarters near the Orleans Cotton Press, about 8 o'clock on the evening of the 23d of April; about one hour afterwards it was reported at the residence of the undersigned by an unknown person that he had been chased into the river by a watchman and was drowned, which is believed to be a ruse to facilitate his escape, as nothing of the kind has yet been ascertained to have occurred. Joe is about 18 years old; his color is black, but not of the deepest shade; he is about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches high; has a large mouth, thick lips and rather a flat nose; is well made, stout, active and intelligent. He had on when he left home a pair of cottonade pantaloons and a hickory shirt. Masters of vessels are hereby warned not to harbor said slave, as the penalties of the law will be enforced against them. C.D. YANCEY. a26 tf
mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections ( http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special )

detail.title: New Orleans daily crescent. ([New Orleans, La.]) 1851-1866

mods.accessCondition: E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments about the collection.

Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain. Permission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Department, Louisiana State University Libraries.
mods.note: Louisiana Runaway Slave Advertisements, 1836-1865, Louisiana Digital Library, Baton Rouge, La.
